author: Trevor Hoey
title: Rio Tinto gains strength in tough climate for miners
text:
Rio Tinto credits its tier-one assets and sound operating capability with delivering stable margins, assisting the group in generating first-half underlying earnings of $2.9 billion. by Trevor Hoey Rio Tinto's interim result for fiscal 2015 drew what could be considered a positive response, given it traded fairly flat on a day that the S&P/ASX 200 Index lost about 130 points.
Headlining the result were comments by chief executive Sam Walsh, who noted that the six months to June 30 had represented a robust performance in tough operating conditions.
He emphasised how the performance of the group's tier-one assets and sound operating capability had delivered stable margins, assisting Rio in generating underlying earnings of $2.9 billion.
In terms of guidance, Mr Walsh said the group would retain tight capital discipline with a focus on cash generation and sustainable returns. On this note he said operating cash cost improvements for the 12 months to December 31, 2015, are expected to be $1 billion, up from previous projections of $750 million.
Capital expenditure is expected to decline to about $5.5 billion in 2015 and less than $6 billion in 2016. Production guidance remains unchanged.
In response to the result, Paul Young from Deutsche Bank said: "We continue to think Rio is the standout big miner on valuation, free cash flow, growth and buybacks. With regards to the latter, management is continuing its share buyback program with $1 billion of Rio Tinto plc shares expected to be purchased in the second half of 2015."
Three times in the past three years Rio's shares have bottomed at about the $50.00 mark before rebounding strongly. This recent rally, just after hitting a 12-month low of $49.13 in July, may be the forerunner to a material re-rating.
Deutsche Bank has a buy recommendation on the stock, with a 12-month price target of $71.00. Citi has also attributed a buy recommendation but is more conservative regarding the group's outlook, with its 12-month target price standing at $58.00.
